captions.text:
Today’s episode of Film Riot brought to
you by Drive San Francisco
Today on Film Riot, we drive fast.

Welcome to Film Riot Mondays, I’m your host
Ryan Connolly.

Now, I found out we were going to be sponsored
in an episode by the awesome Drive: San Francisco

game, which filled me with delight, which
also is neither here nor there. But what is

important is it reminded me of a few e-mails
I've been meaning to answer.

Ry Ry Guy: I want to do the effect where the
camera moves really fast toward something

or through something… ya know what I mean?
I hope you make this an episode.

That wasn't a lot to go off of but I'm pretty
sure I got it
And then there's this e-mail as well…

Hey Film Riot, is there a way to do a car
chase without breaking the speed limit?

I thought these questions suited today quite
nicely so, let's do this thing.

First of all, let’s talk about the shift
of fact, which is the fast moving through

an area and into the car shot that I did.
I say shift affect because that's what happens

in the game, you can transport from one car
to the other like that which is where I got

my motivation from on how to do this. And
you'll be happy to know that this is another

super simple affect so. First thing we need
to do of course, is shoot your footage. For

this I used a mono pod to act as a stabilizer
so I could lift the camera high into the air

and then back down again. If you don't have
a mono pod don't worry any tripod will good
just as well.

So I've got my shot by lifting the mono pod
up high and then walking at no regular pace

towards the back of the car. And once I made
it all the way to the back of the car window,

I cut. I need chose this card because it has
a hatch back and works perfectly to shove

the camera through the back. So I opened the
back and continued to the shot all the way

to the steering wheel where I had Josh grab
on queue.

Now the most important thing to this effect
is how you shoot your footage, you have to

have this entire shot mapped out in your head
so you can move through that area smoothly.

Meaning, if you get to the back of the car
on the left once you're inside the car you

should also be on the left side. If you mess
this up the effect will break and look really
crappy.

So now that the footage is shot you can bring
it in to your editor of choice, I'm going

to use After Effects because it makes it a
lot easier, but you can do the same thing

in pretty much any editor. So inside After
Effects I will stitch my shots together at

the point to where the camera comes against
the back of the car and then, cut to the shot

inside the car. Now, just add a fade to smooth
that transition. Next, it was time to stabilize

the footage, which I was really impressed
with the Adobes built in work stabilizer plug

in, I've been hearing a lot of people talk
about it but I hadn't had the chance to try

it out for myself so, I got to say… me likey,
me likey a whole lot.

So all I needed to do was at the warped stabilizer
to my clip and then let it and a lot of. Once

it's done I can play around with the parameters
without having yet to start at square one

every time and I love that. I love that a
lot.

Now this would still work without stabilization
it just wouldn't look as good since it would

be jerking around a whole lot. But now that
we've got our footage without it being a jerk

were going to pre-comp this and then start
adding time remapping. Again this is very

straightforward and can be done in any editor
since were doing hard stops and starts meaning

there's no ramping. So all you need to do
is speed your footage up between the point

of where it starts and stops moving. So you
can cut at the beginning of the move and your

sweet change, cut when it stopped at another
and so on. Super simple stuff. But now you

should have this, look crappy that's because
we haven't added the blur and again I did

this as easily as possible. For the move up,
I just key framed a directional blur to intensify,

and then dropped down as I stopped and for
the move towards the car, I did the same thing

but with a radial blur instead. Both of these
are basic blur options found in pre-much any

and all editing affects software. But now,
we finally have this. And now to once again

show how much sound and color correction does
for your project, we added the finishing touches
and finely end up with this.

Fun, oh so much fun. And this effect can be
used for a whole lot of different things,

like swishing up the Josh's face like I did,
so take this technique and go crazy, get creative

and take your stuff from here to more fun.
That's the level right? That's a big freakin’
level.

The original developers behind Driver I, the
number one videogame in 1999, period. And

Drive II are back to create ubisoft’s first
driver title. San Francisco is a driver’s

playground, it makes a ton of sense for drivers
to bring it to open world, expertise to city

by the Bay. There's over 200 miles of drivable
roads in this game and its representation,

San Francisco, is amazingly close. The ferry
building, the Transamerica building, the Golden

Gate Bridge you better believe they're all
in the game. Driver is known for its classic

muscle cars, the 1968 Mustang GT fastback,
the 74 Ford Grand Tereno, the 1970s Chevelle

SS, they're all in here. In fact, there's
over 120 license cars within the game. Pick

a car and pulled the throttle. The game is
available now so go get it and drive really

fast without getting a speeding ticket or
a car crash, both things you don't want.

And now back to the shoe, chase scenes are
pretty difficult to do unless you live somewhere

where you can find a lot of empty roads which
I do not. So making it look like you're driving

really fast can be pretty tricky, but, if
you're clever you can definitely pull it off.

So real quick, let's bust out four tips to
look like you're driving fast without breaking
the speed limit.

Number one, move your camera around a lot.
And this really goes for all action really,

the more you move your camera the more exciting
and fast-paced it will seem. If you have a

more stable shot while you are driving 45
miles an hour, if you look like you're driving

45 miles an hour, not too exciting. Of course
don't go too crazy to where your like what

am I watching, and people vomit all over the
place, if you don't want that either.

Number two. Low angles are your friend if
you can get the camera low, do it. This will

also make everything look much faster than
it is and higher angles again it will show
how slow you are actually driving.

Number three, get a plethora of angles, the
more shots you have to work with the better.

Because the more you cut the less time it
your viewer will have to see you were actually

breaking the speed limit. A great advantage
for me was the go code camera, you can do

actually safely mount these mother f’ers
to your car through suction cup mount and

then drive on playa. I was able to get some
pretty cool shots by doing this, like this
one, this one, and this one. Delish.

Number four, sound effects. Sound is your
friend. If you're not good with sound, learn.

If the car sounds like it's going fast, you're
going to perceived it this way. Of course

if you're going 10 miles an hour, it's just
going to be comical. But with all these tips

combined., You get a very convincing effect
without running into the 50.

So there you go, four tips to driving fast
without actually driving fast. Now we plan

to go more in depth with filming a car chase
scene in the future, but since were also finishing

up our short action film Losses, we ran out
of time. Speaking of losses, we’re releasing

our 9 min. action short this Wednesday, and
to say that we're excited would be a massive

understatement. We shot this bad boy on the
red epic and are uploading it in glorious

2K. After it's uploaded, were going to start
releasing episodes showing how we did all

the action. So check out our YouTube on Wednesday
and let us know what you think about our short

film. That’s it, I’ll see you on Thursday
but until then, be safe and don’t forget

to watch Losses, on our You Tube channel.
Where’s it going to be? You tube. When:

Wednesday. Which is the 14th. Probably around
noon, but don’t take o

comments.author: Syke

comments.text:
2 more tips.
Using a wider focal length will make straight forward moves feel faster 
(the wider the better and thats why go pro hero make you feel some sport 
videos are going fast even if its not) 
If you are walking with a camera going straight with a very wide angle you 
will feel like you're running in the video.

with a scene that the car goes from the left to the right or the right to 
the left u might need to use a long focal length (maybe 100-200 mm or so) 
if you move the camera from the right to the left with that focal length, 
you will notice how fast it feels. (dont use wide angle in this because it 
feels slower) 

sorry for my bad english btw. i hope you got my idea :\﻿

comments.author: Moh'd Songoro

comments.text:
Yo Ryan! I think this might help as well:
When taking a tripod shot and tracking the car from one side to the other, 
what I do is make the car drive fast enough and shoot at 24p at a shutter 
speed of 1/24 so that I can get a lot of motion blur from everything but 
the car (If shot and tracked properly of course). After that what I do is 
speed it up in post to 30p and then down-convert the frame rate again to 
24p. It looks really convincing if done properly :D﻿
